name.text: 6.4.2.1 Solving equations involving logarithms and exponentials

questiontext.text:
Solving equations involving logarithms and exponentials

To solve equations which involve logarithms or exponentials we need to be aware of the basic laws which govern both of these mathematical concepts. We illustrate by considering some examples.

Example

Solve for the variable \(x\).

  1. \(3=10^x\)
  2. \(10^{x/4}=\log_{10} 3\)
  3. \(\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\)

Solution

  1. Here we take logs (to base \(10\) because of the term \(10^x\)) of both sides to get \[ \log 3=\log 10^x=x\log 10=x \] where we have used the general property that \(\log_aA^k=k\log_aA\) and the specific property that \(\log 10=1\). Hence \(x=\log 3\) or, in numerical form, \(x=0.47712\) to \(5\) d.p.
  2. The approach used in (a) is used here. Take logs of both sides: \[\log_{10}(10^{x/4})=\log_{10}(\log_{10}3)\] that is \[\dfrac{x}{4}\log_{10} 10=\log_{10} (\log_{10} 3)=\log_{10} (0.4771212)=-0.3213712.\] So, since \(\log_{10} 10=1\), we have \(x=4(-0.3213712)=-1.28549\) to \(5\) d.p.
  3. Here we simplify the expression before taking logs. \[\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\qquad\text{implies}\qquad 1=4(17-e^x)\] or \(4e^x=4(17)-1=67\) so \(e^x=16.75\). Now taking natural logs of both sides (because of the presence of the \(e^x\) term) we have: \[\ln (e^x)=\ln (16.75)=2.8183983.\] But \(\ln (e^x)=x\ln e=x\) and so the solution to \(\dfrac{1}{17-e^x}=4\) is \(x=2.81840\) to \(5\) d.p.
